speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: SCENE II. Belmont. A room in PORTIA'S house.

speaker: SHYLOCK
text_entry: Enter BASSANIO, PORTIA, GRATIANO, NERISSA, and Attendants

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I pray you, tarry: pause a day or two

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Before you hazard; for, in choosing wrong,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I lose your company: therefore forbear awhile.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: There's something tells me, but it is not love,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I would not lose you; and you know yourself,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Hate counsels not in such a quality.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But lest you should not understand me well,--

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And yet a maiden hath no tongue but thought,--

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I would detain you here some month or two

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Before you venture for me. I could teach you

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: How to choose right, but I am then forsworn;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: So will I never be: so may you miss me;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But if you do, you'll make me wish a sin,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That I had been forsworn. Beshrew your eyes,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: They have o'erlook'd me and divided me;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: One half of me is yours, the other half yours,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Mine own, I would say; but if mine, then yours,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And so all yours. O, these naughty times

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Put bars between the owners and their rights!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And so, though yours, not yours. Prove it so,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Let fortune go to hell for it, not I.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I speak too long; but 'tis to peize the time,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To eke it and to draw it out in length,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To stay you from election.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Let me choose

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: For as I am, I live upon the rack.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Upon the rack, Bassanio! then confess

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: What treason there is mingled with your love.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: None but that ugly treason of mistrust,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Which makes me fear the enjoying of my love:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: There may as well be amity and life

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: 'Tween snow and fire, as treason and my love.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Ay, but I fear you speak upon the rack,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Where men enforced do speak anything.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Promise me life, and I'll confess the truth.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Well then, confess and live.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: 'Confess' and 'love'

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Had been the very sum of my confession:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: O happy torment, when my torturer

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Doth teach me answers for deliverance!

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: But let me to my fortune and the caskets.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Away, then! I am lock'd in one of them:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If you do love me, you will find me out.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nerissa and the rest, stand all aloof.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Let music sound while he doth make his choice;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Then, if he lose, he makes a swan-like end,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Fading in music: that the comparison

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: May stand more proper, my eye shall be the stream

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And watery death-bed for him. He may win;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And what is music then? Then music is

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Even as the flourish when true subjects bow

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To a new-crowned monarch: such it is

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: As are those dulcet sounds in break of day

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That creep into the dreaming bridegroom's ear,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And summon him to marriage. Now he goes,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: With no less presence, but with much more love,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Than young Alcides, when he did redeem

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The virgin tribute paid by howling Troy

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To the sea-monster: I stand for sacrifice

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: With bleared visages, come forth to view

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The issue of the exploit. Go, Hercules!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Live thou, I live: with much, much more dismay

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I view the fight than thou that makest the fray.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Music, whilst BASSANIO comments on the caskets to himself

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Tell me where is fancy bred,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Or in the heart, or in the head?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: How begot, how nourished?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Reply, reply.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: It is engender'd in the eyes,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: With gazing fed; and fancy dies

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In the cradle where it lies.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Let us all ring fancy's knell

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I'll begin it,--Ding, dong, bell.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: Ding, dong, bell.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: So may the outward shows be least themselves:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The world is still deceived with ornament.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: In law, what plea so tainted and corrupt,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: But, being seasoned with a gracious voice,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Obscures the show of evil? In religion,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: What damned error, but some sober brow

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Will bless it and approve it with a text,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Hiding the grossness with fair ornament?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: There is no vice so simple but assumes

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Some mark of virtue on his outward parts:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: How many cowards, whose hearts are all as false

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: As stairs of sand, wear yet upon their chins

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Who, inward search'd, have livers white as milk;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And these assume but valour's excrement

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To render them redoubted! Look on beauty,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And you shall see 'tis purchased by the weight;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Which therein works a miracle in nature,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Making them lightest that wear most of it:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: So are those crisped snaky golden locks

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Which make such wanton gambols with the wind,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Upon supposed fairness, often known

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To be the dowry of a second head,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The skull that bred them in the sepulchre.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Thus ornament is but the guiled shore

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To a most dangerous sea; the beauteous scarf

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Veiling an Indian beauty; in a word,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The seeming truth which cunning times put on

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To entrap the wisest. Therefore, thou gaudy gold,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Hard food for Midas, I will none of thee;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Nor none of thee, thou pale and common drudge

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: 'Tween man and man: but thou, thou meagre lead,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Which rather threatenest than dost promise aught,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Thy paleness moves me more than eloquence;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And here choose I; joy be the consequence!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: [Aside]  How all the other passions fleet to air,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: As doubtful thoughts, and rash-embraced despair,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And shuddering fear, and green-eyed jealousy! O love,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Be moderate; allay thy ecstasy,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: In measure rein thy joy; scant this excess.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I feel too much thy blessing: make it less,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For fear I surfeit.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: What find I here?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Opening the leaden casket

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Fair Portia's counterfeit! What demi-god

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Hath come so near creation? Move these eyes?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Or whether, riding on the balls of mine,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Seem they in motion? Here are sever'd lips,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Parted with sugar breath: so sweet a bar

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Should sunder such sweet friends. Here in her hairs

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The painter plays the spider and hath woven

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: A golden mesh to entrap the hearts of men,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Faster than gnats in cobwebs; but her eyes,--

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: How could he see to do them? having made one,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Methinks it should have power to steal both his

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And leave itself unfurnish'd. Yet look, how far

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The substance of my praise doth wrong this shadow

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: In underprizing it, so far this shadow

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Doth limp behind the substance. Here's the scroll,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The continent and summary of my fortune.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Reads

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: You that choose not by the view,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Chance as fair and choose as true!

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Since this fortune falls to you,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Be content and seek no new,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: If you be well pleased with this

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And hold your fortune for your bliss,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Turn you where your lady is

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And claim her with a loving kiss.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: A gentle scroll. Fair lady, by your leave;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I come by note, to give and to receive.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Like one of two contending in a prize,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: That thinks he hath done well in people's eyes,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Hearing applause and universal shout,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Whether these pearls of praise be his or no;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: So, thrice fair lady, stand I, even so;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: As doubtful whether what I see be true,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Until confirm'd, sign'd, ratified by you.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You see me, Lord Bassanio, where I stand,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Such as I am: though for myself alone

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I would not be ambitious in my wish,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To wish myself much better; yet, for you

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I would be trebled twenty times myself;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A thousand times more fair, ten thousand times more rich;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That only to stand high in your account,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I might in virtue, beauties, livings, friends,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Exceed account; but the full sum of me

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is sum of something, which, to term in gross,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is an unlesson'd girl, unschool'd, unpractised;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Happy in this, she is not yet so old

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But she may learn; happier than this,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: She is not bred so dull but she can learn;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Happiest of all is that her gentle spirit

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Commits itself to yours to be directed,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: As from her lord, her governor, her king.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Myself and what is mine to you and yours

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is now converted: but now I was the lord

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Of this fair mansion, master of my servants,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Queen o'er myself: and even now, but now,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: This house, these servants and this same myself

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Are yours, my lord: I give them with this ring;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which when you part from, lose, or give away,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Let it presage the ruin of your love

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And be my vantage to exclaim on you.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Madam, you have bereft me of all words,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Only my blood speaks to you in my veins;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And there is such confusion in my powers,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: As after some oration fairly spoke

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: By a beloved prince, there doth appear

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Among the buzzing pleased multitude;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Where every something, being blent together,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Turns to a wild of nothing, save of joy,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Express'd and not express'd. But when this ring

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Parts from this finger, then parts life from hence:

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: O, then be bold to say Bassanio's dead!

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: My lord and lady, it is now our time,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: That have stood by and seen our wishes prosper,

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: To cry, good joy: good joy, my lord and lady!

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: My lord Bassanio and my gentle lady,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I wish you all the joy that you can wish;

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: For I am sure you can wish none from me:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And when your honours mean to solemnize

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: The bargain of your faith, I do beseech you,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Even at that time I may be married too.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: With all my heart, so thou canst get a wife.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I thank your lordship, you have got me one.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: My eyes, my lord, can look as swift as yours:

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: You saw the mistress, I beheld the maid;

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: You loved, I loved for intermission.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: No more pertains to me, my lord, than you.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Your fortune stood upon the casket there,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And so did mine too, as the matter falls;

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: For wooing here until I sweat again,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: And sweating until my very roof was dry

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: With oaths of love, at last, if promise last,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I got a promise of this fair one here

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: To have her love, provided that your fortune

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Achieved her mistress.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is this true, Nerissa?

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: Madam, it is, so you stand pleased withal.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And do you, Gratiano, mean good faith?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Yes, faith, my lord.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Our feast shall be much honour'd in your marriage.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: We'll play with them the first boy for a thousand ducats.

speaker: NERISSA
text_entry: What, and stake down?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: No; we shall ne'er win at that sport, and stake down.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: But who comes here? Lorenzo and his infidel? What,

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: and my old Venetian friend Salerio?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Enter LORENZO, JESSICA, and SALERIO, a Messenger from Venice

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome hither;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: If that the youth of my new interest here

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Have power to bid you welcome. By your leave,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I bid my very friends and countrymen,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Sweet Portia, welcome.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: So do I, my lord:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: They are entirely welcome.

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: I thank your honour. For my part, my lord,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: My purpose was not to have seen you here;

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: But meeting with Salerio by the way,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: He did entreat me, past all saying nay,

speaker: LORENZO
text_entry: To come with him along.

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: I did, my lord;

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: And I have reason for it. Signior Antonio

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Commends him to you.

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Gives Bassanio a letter

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Ere I ope his letter,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I pray you, tell me how my good friend doth.

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Not sick, my lord, unless it be in mind;

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Nor well, unless in mind: his letter there

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Will show you his estate.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Nerissa, cheer yon stranger; bid her welcome.

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: Your hand, Salerio: what's the news from Venice?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: How doth that royal merchant, good Antonio?

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: I know he will be glad of our success;

speaker: GRATIANO
text_entry: We are the Jasons, we have won the fleece.

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: I would you had won the fleece that he hath lost.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: There are some shrewd contents in yon same paper,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That steals the colour from Bassanio's cheek:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Some dear friend dead; else nothing in the world

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Could turn so much the constitution

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Of any constant man. What, worse and worse!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: With leave, Bassanio: I am half yourself,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And I must freely have the half of anything

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That this same paper brings you.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: O sweet Portia,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Here are a few of the unpleasant'st words

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: That ever blotted paper! Gentle lady,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: When I did first impart my love to you,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I freely told you, all the wealth I had

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Ran in my veins, I was a gentleman;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And then I told you true: and yet, dear lady,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Rating myself at nothing, you shall see

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: How much I was a braggart. When I told you

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: My state was nothing, I should then have told you

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: That I was worse than nothing; for, indeed,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I have engaged myself to a dear friend,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Engaged my friend to his mere enemy,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: To feed my means. Here is a letter, lady;

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The paper as the body of my friend,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And every word in it a gaping wound,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Issuing life-blood. But is it true, Salerio?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Have all his ventures fail'd? What, not one hit?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: From Tripolis, from Mexico and England,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: From Lisbon, Barbary and India?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: And not one vessel 'scape the dreadful touch

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Of merchant-marring rocks?

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Not one, my lord.

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Besides, it should appear, that if he had

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: The present money to discharge the Jew,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: He would not take it. Never did I know

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: A creature, that did bear the shape of man,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: So keen and greedy to confound a man:

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: He plies the duke at morning and at night,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: And doth impeach the freedom of the state,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: If they deny him justice: twenty merchants,

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: The duke himself, and the magnificoes

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Of greatest port, have all persuaded with him;

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: But none can drive him from the envious plea

speaker: SALERIO
text_entry: Of forfeiture, of justice and his bond.

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: When I was with him I have heard him swear

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: That he would rather have Antonio's flesh

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: Than twenty times the value of the sum

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: That he did owe him: and I know, my lord,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: If law, authority and power deny not,

speaker: JESSICA
text_entry: It will go hard with poor Antonio.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The dearest friend to me, the kindest man,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The best-condition'd and unwearied spirit

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: In doing courtesies, and one in whom

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: The ancient Roman honour more appears

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Than any that draws breath in Italy.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: What sum owes he the Jew?

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: For me three thousand ducats.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: What, no more?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Pay him six thousand, and deface the bond;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Double six thousand, and then treble that,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Before a friend of this description

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Shall lose a hair through Bassanio's fault.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: First go with me to church and call me wife,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And then away to Venice to your friend;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For never shall you lie by Portia's side

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: With an unquiet soul. You shall have gold

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To pay the petty debt twenty times over:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: When it is paid, bring your true friend along.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: My maid Nerissa and myself meantime

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Will live as maids and widows. Come, away!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For you shall hence upon your wedding-day:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Since you are dear bought, I will love you dear.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But let me hear the letter of your friend.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: [Reads]  Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: miscarried, my creditors grow cruel, my estate is

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: very low, my bond to the Jew is forfeit; and since

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: in paying it, it is impossible I should live, all

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: debts are cleared between you and I, if I might but

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: see you at my death. Notwithstanding, use your

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: pleasure: if your love do not persuade you to come,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: let not my letter.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: O love, dispatch all business, and be gone!

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Since I have your good leave to go away,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: I will make haste: but, till I come again,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay,

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: No rest be interposer 'twixt us twain.

speaker: BASSANIO
text_entry: Exeunt
